data.Title: Dialogue Across Differences
data.Location: Iowa Valley Community College: 123 6th Avenue, Grinnell
data.Description:
Join the Grinnell ALLiance for a transformative two-day Dialogue Across Differences Community Gathering. This is an opportunity to meet new people, build relationships, foster understanding, and shape the future of our shared community. Whether you’re a lifelong resident or new to Grinnell, a student, an employee or a resident, this gathering is for anyone who cares deeply about making our community stronger, more connected, and better for everyone. We value diverse perspectives, and we want your voice in the room.


  The gathering will be facilitated by Posse Consulting, recognized nationally for leadership development and building community. This is a 2-day event and to ensure a meaningful experience for all participants, we ask that you commit to attending the entire gathering.


  This event will include activities that range from thought-provoking discussions to creative group exercises. You’ll have the chance to explore your own perspectives, hear others’ stories, and work together to envision a stronger, more connected community.


  You are invited to attend at no cost, but space is limited, so please by March 15.


  You can register ONLINE, EMAIL or via phone at 641.351.7736.


  The event is made possible by support from Iowa State Historical Society Humanities Grant, The Grinnell Racial Equity Fund, Iowa Valley Community College, The City of Grinnell, Grinnell Mutual, Grinnell College, REMAX, Latitude Signage + Design, Grinnell Ministerial Association, Hotel Grinnell, Temp Associates, Community Education Collaborative, HyVee, First Presbyterian Church, Ahrens Foundation, and others.

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.
data.Org: Crssj, Student Affairs, Student Health & Wellness

data.Title: Philosophy Candidate Job Talk
data.Description: Philosophy Candidate Job Talk

data.Title: Zhange Ni Presentation
data.Description:
Abstract of the talk:


  The Cthulhu Mythos is a collection of horror stories positing the existence of Cthulhu and other monsters and the inevitable demise of human civilization in an indifferent cosmos. Cultivations novels are a fantasy genre telling stories about how practitioners of internal alchemy achieve immortality and explore infinite worlds. The Cthulhu Mythos was first invented in America between the two world wars in the twentieth century, while cultivation novels emerged in the twenty-first century when China ascended as a global power. The two fictional universes, the former loaded with anti-humanist sentiments and the latter celebrating ultra-humanism, have converged in Cthulhu-cultivation novels and transformed one another. While both systems draw on esoteric traditions around the world and enact apocalyptic worldviews and “blasphemous” practices, the new hybrid, Cthulhu-cultivation novels, are particularly worthy of our attention because they have been experimenting with engaged nihilism, that is, a critical response to social issues, a hostility toward established power structures, and a call for radical changes.
data.Org: Chinese Japanese Department, East Asian Concentration, Religious Studies

data.Title: Learn about GrinnBooks
data.Description:
Talk to the staff from the Pioneer Bookshop to learn about the new textbook resource program named GrinnBooks. 


  Starting in Fall 2025, your required textbooks will be included in the comprehensive fee.  You receive your digital textbooks through Pioneer Web.  Your physical books will be picked up at that Pioneer Bookshop.  All with no extra cost to you.

data.Title: Summer Independent Projects Workshop
data.Description:
Want to develop skills, gain experience, and tailor it to your specific interests? An independent project might be perfect for you! All class years and all majors welcome.


  Dani Perkins and Destini Ross of the CLS will discuss how to develop an independent project, best practices, and generate ideas. This is a great option if you don’t have a formal summer experience lined up, or have a gap this summer between experiences you want to fill with something meaningful.


  Register on Handshake at: Summer Independent Projects Workshop | Handshake


  Email Destini Ross, Associate Director; Arts, Media and Communications Career Community in the Center for Careers, Life and Service for questions or accommodations.
data.Org: Center For Careers Life And Service
